stem: The home health nurse is auditing the medication storage for a client with diabetes who lives alone. Based on the documentation in the Medication Storage & Expiration Log, match each finding with the correct nursing action.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
Patient: Ms. Thompson, 68 years old. Recently discharged. Uses Insulin Glargine (long-acting) and Insulin Lispro (rapid-acting).
Nurse Observation: Client has multiple vials on the kitchen counter and several in the refrigerator.
Goal: Ensure insulin efficacy and safety.

tabs.title: Medication Storage & Expiration Log
tabs.content:
Insulin VialStorage LocationDate OpenedCurrent Appearance
Glargine (Opened)Kitchen Counter (72°F)25 days agoClear
Lispro (Opened)Kitchen Counter (72°F)35 days agoCloudy (Should be clear)
NPH (Unopened)Refrigerator (38°F)NeverCloudy (Normal)

tabs.title: Insulin Handling Standards
tabs.content:
1. Unopened vials should be refrigerated (36°F–46°F).
2. Opened vials may stay at room temperature for up to 28–30 days.
3. NEVER freeze insulin.
4. Inspect for changes in appearance (clumping, frosting, or cloudiness in clear insulin).

rows.text: Unopened vials stored in the refrigerator (36°F–46°F).
Opened vial stored at room temperature for 25 days.
Clear insulin (Lispro/Regular) that has become cloudy or frosted.
Opened vial stored at room temperature for 35 days.

rationale.correct: Unopened insulin (r1) belongs in the refrigerator (c1). Opened insulin (r2) is stable for approximately 30 days at room temperature (c1). Insulin that has been frozen (r3), is past its 30-day opening limit (r5), or has changed in clarity/clumping (r4) is unstable and must be discarded (c2).
clinicalPearls: Room temperature insulin is less painful to inject than cold insulin.
Always label the vial with the DATE OPENED, not just the date it arrived.
Check the manufacturer's insert, but 28-30 days is the standard NCLEX rule for opened vials.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking that 'cloudy' is always a bad thing in insulin.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Only bad for clear insulins. NPH is NORMALLY cloudy. You must know which should be which!

mnemonic.title: The 30-Day Rule
mnemonic.expansion: Once it's open and out of the cold, 30 days and it's too old.
